dc:description:
The relationship between SSBP1 and optic atrophy with negative Electroretinograms, an autosomal dominant disorder, was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of May, 2021. SSBP1 encodes the single-stranded DNA-binding protein 1. It is a housekeeping gene involved in mitochondrial biogenesis and is a subunit of a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA)-binding complex. optic atrophy with negative Electroretinograms (also referred to as Optic atrophy 13 with retinal and foveal abnormalities) is characterized by bilateral optic atrophy, foveopathy, loss of vision/color vision and retinal pigmentary defects, in some cases (Jurkute t al, 2019; PMID: 31298765). 

SSBP1 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant optic atrophy with negative Electroretinograms in 2019. (Jurkute et al; PMID: 31298765). At least 8 missense variants have been reported in humans thus far. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data.  
   
Summary of Case Level Data (12 points):
Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 13 probands in 4 publications ( PMID: 31298765,  31550237, 31550240, 31479473). Variants segregated with disease in several (>40) additional family members. All variants reported are missense, and are found to recur across families. A founder effect has not been reported, but is likely. The mechanism for disease is expected to be dominant negative resulting in a loss of function of the wild-type protein.  
  
Summary of experimental data (3.5 points):
This gene-disease association is supported by in vitro functional assays and animal models. SSBP1 is found to be ubiquitously expressed, and is especially abundant in the retina (PMID: 31298765, 31550237). SSBP1 alterations affect mitochondrial morphogenesis as seen experimentally and in patients (PMID: 28638454). Several groups have studied the effects of SSBP1 variation in zebrafish models, which recapitulate the human phenotype (PMID: 31298765, 31550237, 31550240). Re-introduction of wild-type SSBP1 rescues the phenotype in the zebrafish model (PMID: 31298765).  
  
In summary, there is strong evidence to support the relationship between SSBP1 and autosomal dominant optic atrophy with negative Electroretinograms. Three years must elapse from the first proposal of the association to reach a definitive classification.

evidence.dc:description: The proband was found to carry a de novo heterozygous missense variant, Gly40Val. Functional evidence in zebrafish model revealed that the variant caused loss of function. Mitochondrial depletion was apparent in analysis of patient fibroblasts. The variant was found to result in accumulation of dimeric and trimeric forms of SSBP1. The proband is scored maximum points for de novo variant with confirmed maternity and paternity and functional evidence.
Functional evidence in zebrafish model revealed that the variant caused loss of function.

The proband and his son were heterozygous for the variant. The variant was confirmed to be de novo in the proband, with maternity and paternity confirmed as a consequence of WES analysis. Functional analysis in zebrafish model revealed that the variant resulted in loss of function, with effects similar to the ssbp1-knockdown zebrafish. Mitochondrial depletion was apparent in analysis of patient fibroblasts. The variant was found to result in accumulation of dimeric and trimeric forms of SSBP1. Owing to the functional evidence and confirmation of de novo with maternity and paternity, the proband is scored maximum points.
Functional analysis in zebrafish model revealed that the variant resulted in loss of function, with effects similar to the ssbp1-knockdown zebrafish.

evidence.rdfs:label: Jurkute_Family 1

member.rdfs:label: Jurkute_Family 1_Proband 4-12
member.detectionMethod: Linkage analysis was performed based on autosomal dominant inheritance, assuming complete penetrance and a disease allele frequency of 0.0001. All exons of protein-coding genes, including 100 bp of flanking intron sequence and 1 kb of promoter regions and known miRNAs within the linkage interval were sequenced.  In addition, proband was recruited for analysis by whole-genome sequencing as part of the 100000 genomes project.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Proband had disease onset in adolescence, at age 17y, with bilateral optic disc atrophy, which was noted before the development of retinal vessel attenuation (36y) or retinal pigmentary changes (49y). Hypoplastic optic nerves were noted. Retinal examination revealed different degrees of vessel attenuation, abnormal appearance of the fovea, and retinal pigmentary changes in the midperiphery. Pattern reversal VEPs were undetectable. Best corrected visual acuity (log minimal angle of resolution): both eyes: 3.0. Proband also had exotropia. ERGs showed rod-cone dysfunction at age 46y. PERG P50 was undetectable; severe macular involvement noted. PVEP was undetectable, with possible optic nerve dysfunction. It is not noted if the patients were evaluated for nephropathy and hearing loss.
member.previousTestingDescription: OPA1 variants and the 3 most common Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) variants, m.3460G>A (MTND1), m.11778G>A (MTND4), and m.14484T>C (MTND6) were ruled out.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: All affected individuals in the family had bilateral optic atrophy and reduction of the peripapillary retinal nerve fiber layer and a thin choroid with onset in childhood.

evidence.dc:description: Several obligate carriers were counted in the 7-generation large pedigree.
evidence.rdfs:label: Piro-Megy_Family A

member.rdfs:label: Piro-Megy_Family A_V:11
member.detectionMethod: WES was performed on seven affected individuals in the family. Sanger sequencing confirmed segregation of the variant in additional members of the family.
member.phenotypeFreeText: All affected individuals in the family had a bilateral pallor of the temporal neuroretinal rim. Visual acuity ranged from 20/400 to 20/20. Central, coecocentral, and paracentral scotomas with preserved peripheral isopters were identified. Visual acuity: 20/800 (both eyes), temporal pallor, RNFL thickness: N 40/39, S 54/49, I 122/115; Foveal thickness: T 9/10, Deutan color defect, foveopathy
member.previousTestingDescription: Mutations were ruled out in genes previously associated with ADOA or maculopathy

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: All affected individuals in the family had a bilateral pallor of the temporal neuroretinal rim. Visual acuity ranged from 20/400 to 20/20. Protan or deutan color defects were noted. Central, coecocentral, and paracentral scotomas with preserved peripheral isopters were identified.

evidence.dc:description: The proband was heterozygous for the missense variant. Functional analysis in zebrafish model revealed loss of function due to the variant. The proband is scored default points.
Functional analysis in zebrafish model revealed loss of function due to the variant.

The proband and her sister had optic atrophy and the Arg38Gln missense variant. The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765. It is scored reduced points in this instance. Note, it was scored increased points in PMID: 31298765.
The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765.

The proband was homozygous for the missense variant, Ile132Val, which is classified as a VUS in ClinVar. The patient's phenotype is non-specific. However, functional evidence in zebrafish showed a loss of function phenotype, and experiments in patient fibroblasts showed that the variant interfered with SSBP1 multimerization. The authors however note that the effect due to this variant is mild. The proband is not scored due to the homozygosity of the variant.
functional evidence in zebrafish showed a loss of function phenotype

The proband had optic atrophy and the Arg107Gln missense variant. The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765. It is scored reduced points in this instance. Note, it was scored increased points in PMID: 31298765.
The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765.
The proband was heterozygous for the Arg38Gln missense variant. Reduced points are awarded for the proband. Note, the variant was previously scored in another proband in Family 2 in PMID: 31298765.

Expression of the variant in zebrafish model resulted in reduced retinal atoh7 expression, similar to the ssb1-knockout model. Mutant ssb1 was found to compete with endogenous or exogenous WT ssb1, indicating a dominant negative effect, with loss of wild-type protein function.

The proband had optic atrophy and the Arg107Gln missense variant. The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765. It is scored reduced points in this instance. Note, it was scored increased points in PMID: 31298765.
The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765.

The proband was heterozygous for the missense variant, Glu27Lys. the mechanism of disease due to this variant is not clearly understood. It does not affect the multimerization of SSBP1 or weaken its DNA-binding ability. The authors suggest that the variant may affect the mobility of SSBP1 tetramers. The variant is de novo with maternity and paternity confirmed. However, given the variable phenotype of the patient and the presence of the mtDNA deletion, as well as lack of functional characterization, the variant is scored default points for a de novo variant.
The proband was heterozygous for the Arg107Gln missense variant, as were several others within the family. Increased points are awarded for functional evidence in animal model.

Expression of the variant in zebrafish model resulted in reduced retinal atoh7 expression, similar to the ssb1-knockout model. Mutant ssb1 was found to compete with endogenous or exogenous WT ssb1, indicating a dominant negative effect, with loss of wild-type protein function.

The proband had optic atrophy and the Arg107Gln missense variant. The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765. It is scored reduced points in this instance. Note, it was scored increased points in PMID: 31298765.
The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765.
The proband was heterozygous for the Arg38Gln missense variant, as were two others within the family. Increased points are awarded for functional evidence in animal model.

Expression of the variant in zebrafish model resulted in reduced retinal atoh7 expression, similar to the ssb1-knockout model. Mutant ssb1 was found to compete with endogenous or exogenous WT ssb1, indicating a dominant negative effect, with loss of wild-type protein function.

The proband and several others within the family had optic atrophy and the Arg38Gln missense variant. The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765. It is scored reduced points in this instance. Note, it was scored increased points in PMID: 31298765. Western blot analysis in patient fibroblasts revealed markedly reduced SSBP1. mtDNA depletion, reduced TFAM and POLG1 protein levels, and 75% reduction of anti-DNA immunofluorescence in mitochondrial nuceloids was also apparent. Also note, at least 3 instances within the article refer to the variant as Arg38Glu. This is likely a typo.
The variant is supported by functional evidence from PMID: 31298765.
The proband was heterozygous for the missense variant. Functional evidence in zebrafish model revealed a loss of function mechanism due to the variant. The proband is scored default points.
Functional evidence in zebrafish model revealed a loss of function mechanism due to the variant.
The proband was heterozygous for the Ser141Ser synonymous variant. Increased points are awarded for the proband with the variant with functional evidence in animal model.

Expression of the variant in zebrafish model resulted in reduced retinal atoh7 expression, similar to the ssb1-knockout model. Mutant ssb1 was found to compete with endogenous or exogenous WT ssb1, indicating a dominant negative effect, with loss of wild-type protein function.

The morphological changes observed in the model system are consistent with the human phenotype of optic atrophy. Default points are awarded. PMID: 31550240 also performed experiments is zebrafish, showing similar optic nerve defects.

Knockdown of ssbp1 resulted in impaired initiation of retinal ganglion cell differentiation and retinal integrity in zebrafish. The expression of developmental regulator genes, isl1 and atoh7, was strongly reduced in retinal ganglion cell precursors. Nonphotoreceptor cells both in the ganglion cell layer and, likely secondarily, in the inner nuclear layer, displayed compromised neuronal specification, whereas cell numbers in both layers were unaltered. The optic nerve, consisting of RGC axons, was much thinner, consistent with the axonal deficiencies of peripheral neurons.
evidence.rdfs:label: Jurkute_Zebrafish model

evidence.dc:description: Minimal points are awarded as the rescue evidence is limited and the authors do not show the associated data.
Re-introduction of the wild-type ssbp1 mRNA led to significant alleviation of retinal defects resulting from knockdown of ssbp1.
evidence.rdfs:label: Jurkute_Rescue in zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: Default points are scored based on expert review.
Fibroblasts from patients with SSBP1 variants show mtDNA deletion and depletion as well as reduced protein levels of TFAM and POLG1 and reduced area and volume of nucleoids.
evidence.rdfs:label: Wang_mitochondrial dysfunction

evidence.dc:description: DAB immunohistochemistry confirmed that SSBP1 is abundant in all the layers of the retina in 2mo mouse eye. Authors also found it colocalized with mitochondria and mitochondrial nucleoids in SH-SY5Y cells labeled with mitotracker and anti-TFAM. In zebrafish, authors note that ssbp1 is ubiquitously expressed during development, including in the retina.
evidence.rdfs:label: Jurkute_Expression
